bibl.title: Letter from J. N. Kenealy to Richard M. Hewitt, July 9, 1946

div1.p: Kenealy forwards Moran's address to Hewitt. Kenealy met Moran in 1908 and recalls that he was proud of his role in the yellow fever experiments.

div1.head: Letter from J. N. Kenealy to Richard M. Hewitt, July 9, 1946
div1.opener:
Box 1437, Balboa, C. Z.
July 9, 1946.
Richard M. Hewitt, M.D.,
Mayo Clinic,
Rochester, Minn.
Dear Dr. Hewitt:
div1.p:
My brother-in-law, Mr. Peter G. Flynn, just returned
from treatment in your clinic has told me that you were inter-
ested in contacting some member of the group of volunteers in
the original yellow fever experiment in Cuba.

“Pete” is so enthusiastic, appreciative, etc. of the
favors, kindness, consideration shown him by all with whom he
came in contact that in this instance and in your case I am
endeavouring to be of some small help in locating Mr. John J.
Moran, a Volunteer, in the “contagion” group of the experiment
you are interested in.
Mr. John J. Moran,
804 Entre B y C, Vedado,
Habana, Cuba.

The above address I secured from a nephew of his;
also the information that he is a Manager for the Sacony Gas-
oline Corp. in that city. It is particularly fortunate that
he is resident of that particular city as I understand one of
your main questions has to deal with the site of the huts in
which they underwent their various tests. His nephew informs
me that he has been living there for the past twenty years: a
point which should lend weight to any testimony he might be
able to give as to the site of the tests.

The construction of the Canal drew a great percentage
of ex-amry men; veterans of Cuba, Puerto Rico and the Philip-
pines. Mr. Moran was one of what we here call “The Old Timers”.
Although from all parts of the “States”, the Spanish-American
group had many common contacts and we have a considerable fund
knowledge of each other now extending into the second and third
generation - similar to any other small community.

Meeting Mr. Moran only once, back in early 1908, I
have a distinct recollection of the man and his record. My
Father talked much of him and I have meeting others and hearing
the old war stories kept my early impressions. He was proud
of his part in that early experiment and I am sure will today
as cheerfully render all help in his power to complete the re-
cord and render all homage to that great man - William Crawford
Gorgas. Pete asks to be remmemberd to his friends.
